document_data.name: Duar Obarskyr
document_data.dobnotes: {{Cite dragon/279/The New Adventures of Volo: Lost Treasures of Cormyr, Part 2|83}}
document_data.deathnotes: {{Cite dragon/279/The New Adventures of Volo: Lost Treasures of Cormyr, Part 2|82}}
document_data.mainbody: King '''Duar "Longyears" Obarskyr''' was the 52{{nd}} monarch in the [[Obarskyr]] dynasty and ruler of [[Cormyr]] from the {{YearlinkName|425}}, to the {{YearlinkName|480}}.Irongates was a holding northeast of Wheloon and Jarthroon was west of Suzail on a rocky ridge overlooking the [[Dragonmere]]. Both settlements disappeared into history.
document_data.Description: Duar was extremely large and muscular, reaching nearly {{SI|7|ft|long=yes}} tall. He had dark blue (nearly black) eyes and brown hair. He developed streaks of gray in his hair and short beard relatively early in his life. In battle, he wielded a large [[two-handed sword]] in one hand and a devastating [[heavy mace]] in the other.
document_data.Personality:
King Duar was a strong and capable warlord with a gruff exterior. His third wife, the Lady [[Jhanthyl Lagarr]], however, found him to be understanding and even gentle, despite having led the forces that killed her husband, Lord [[Kuthor Lagarr]], in battle.

During his reign, he called [[Castle Obarskyr]] "Helmstar Castle" because he claimed the name came to him in a dream.
document_data.Possessions: Duar possessed the sword [[Orbyn]], crafted for him by [[Amedahast]].
document_data.Relationships: Duar's father was [[Azoun Obarskyr I]]. Duar's first wife was [[Daverna Turcassan]], the daughter of Lord [[Melineth Turcassan|Melineth]] from the noble house of [[Turcassan]] before its disgrace. His second wife was [[Threena Cormaeril]] who gave birth to a son, [[Galaghard Obarskyr I|Galaghard]]. After she died, Duar married Jhanthyl Lagarr.
document_data.History:
Duar was born in the {{YearlinkName|385}}, and inherited the throne upon his father's death in the {{YearlinkName|425}}.

In the {{YearlinkName|429}}, he took an army to the [[King's Forest]] to battle [[orc]] invaders, but while he was gone, his father-in-law, Melineth Turcassan, sold the city of [[Suzail]] to pirates for the price of 500 sacks of gold. A price was put on Duar's head by [[Magrath the Minotaur]] but there were few who dared try to collect it.

With the help of Threena, who had entered into a marriage with [[Lord Dheolur]] in order to spy on him and his traitorous machinations, Duar killed both Dheolur and Magrath in the {{YearlinkName|432}}, and reclaimed Suzail. and soon thereafter, he married Threena.

In the {{YearlinkName|475}}, King Duar felt it necessary to challenge a perceived threat to the integrity of Cormyrâ€”the newly constructed castle of [[Irongates Gard]], erected by the cruel but prosperous warlord, Kuthor Lagarr. After Kuthor fell in battle, his wife, Jhanthyl took up a weapon and fought alongside the remaining knights. She agreed to surrender to Duar only if the rest of her people were allowed to live. Duar treated her well and, after Queen Threena passed away, they married. Duar died less than five years later in the {{YearlinkName|480}}, and Queen Jhanthyl mourned him greatly.

King Duar was succeeded by his son, Galaghard.
